options.text: Assonance refers to the repetition of consonant sounds, while consonance refers to the repetition of vowel sounds.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the hygiene hypothesis?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that an immune system exposed to more pathogens is more likely to develop allergies

options.label: B
options.text: The idea that an immune system exposed to fewer pathogens is more likely to develop allergies

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that an immune system exposed to a variety of microbes is more likely to develop allergies

multiple-choice.question: What is immunotherapy, and how does it work?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Immunotherapy is a type of treatment that uses steroids to reduce inflammation

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: Gravity

options.label: D
options.text: Black holes

multiple-choice.question: What is the Big Rip scenario, and what would happen to the universe in this scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: The universe would expand slowly, and matter would stay intact.

options.label: B
options.text: The universe would expand so fast that space would expand faster than the speed of light, and atoms would disband, and the universe would dissolve into countless lonely particles.

options.label: C
options.text: The universe would contract, and matter would be converted into radiation.

options.label: D
options.text: The universe would remain the same, and there would be no change.

options.label: A
options.text: In the Big Rip scenario, matter stays intact, while in heat death, matter decays and spreads out.

options.label: B
options.text: In the Big Rip scenario, the universe expands forever, while in heat death, the universe turns dark and eventually dies.

options.label: C
options.text: In the Big Rip scenario, the universe contracts, while in heat death, the universe expands.

options.label: D
options.text: In the Big Rip scenario, the universe remains the same, while in heat death, the universe changes.

options.label: A
options.text: The universe would expand, and matter would be converted into radiation.

options.label: B
options.text: The universe would contract, and galaxies would merge, eventually leading to a supermassive mega-black hole.

options.label: C
options.text: The universe would remain the same, and there would be no change.

options.label: D
options.text: The universe would expand slowly, and matter would stay intact.

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The universe would remain the same, and there would be no change.

title: Making sense of irrational numbers - Ganesh Pai

multiple-choice.question: What was the crime of the philosopher Hippasus according to Greek mythology?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: He discovered irrational numbers.

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What was the Pythagorean worldview that Hippasus challenged?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: That numbers are the building blocks of the universe.

options.label: C
options.text: That all shapes are perfect spheres.

options.label: D
options.text: That the diagonal of a square is always an integer.

multiple-choice.question: How did Hippasus prove that the square root of 2 is irrational?

options.label: A
options.text: He showed that it can be expressed as a ratio of two integers.

options.label: B
options.text: He assumed that it can be expressed as a ratio of two integers and then showed that this assumption leads to a contradiction.

options.label: C
options.text: He used a geometric proof to show that the diagonal of a square is always irrational.

options.label: D
options.text: He used a numerical proof to show that the square root of 2 is always an integer.

multiple-choice.question: What is a key difference between rational and irrational numbers?

options.label: A
options.text: Rational numbers can be expressed as decimals, while irrational numbers can only be expressed as ratios.

options.label: B
options.text: Irrational numbers can be precisely plotted on the number line, while rational numbers cannot.

options.label: C
options.text: Rational numbers can be expressed as ratios of integers, while irrational numbers cannot.

options.label: D
options.text: Irrational numbers are always integers, while rational numbers are always decimals.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of Hippasus's discovery of irrational numbers?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to a complete overhaul of the Pythagorean worldview.

options.label: B
options.text: It revolutionized mathematics and had a lasting impact on the field.

options.label: C
options.text: It led to a decline in interest in mathematics among the general population.

options.label: D
options.text: It had no significant impact on the development of mathematics.

options.label: B
options.text: Conjunction fallacy

options.text: Anchoring effect

options.label: D
options.text: Rational economic theory

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is an example of a conjunction fallacy?

options.label: A
options.text: Expecting to see more green rolls when rolling a die with four green faces and two red faces.

options.label: B
options.text: Choosing the shorter sequence of rolls when given two options.

options.label: C
options.text: Expecting to see more red rolls when rolling a die with four green faces and two red faces.

options.label: D
options.text: Choosing the less likely option when given two options.

multiple-choice.question: What is the anchoring effect, and how is it used in marketing and negotiations?

options.label: A
options.text: The anchoring effect is a cognitive bias that affects our estimates of numbers, and it is used to lower prices that people are willing to pay.

options.label: B
options.text: The anchoring effect is a cognitive bias that affects our estimates of numbers, and it is used to raise prices that people are willing to pay.

options.label: C
options.text: The anchoring effect is a cognitive bias that affects our estimates of probability, and it is used to raise the prices that people are willing to pay.

options.label: D
options.text: The anchoring effect is a cognitive bias that affects our estimates of probability, and it is used to lower the prices that people are willing to pay.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are never used in modern decision-making.

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: To identify the source of a substance.

options.label: C
options.text: To determine the age of a substance.

options.label: D
options.text: To determine the weight of a substance.

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of the Large Hadron Collider, a separation technique used to study the universe?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a new, more powerful form of energy.

options.label: B
options.text: To discover the most elementary particle in the universe.

options.label: C
options.text: To understand the origins of the universe.

options.label: D
options.text: To develop new materials and technologies.

title: What Teachers Make

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's response to the dinner guest who asks him to be honest about what he makes?

options.label: A
options.text: He says he makes a lot of money.

options.label: B
options.text: He says he makes kids work harder than they ever thought they could.

options.label: C
options.text: He says he doesn't make anything.

options.label: D
options.text: He says he's just a teacher.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's policy in his classroom about honesty and consequences?

options.label: A
options.text: If you ask for honesty, you have to face the consequences.

options.label: B
options.text: If you ask for honesty, you have to be rewarded.

options.label: C
options.text: If you ask for honesty, you have to let the other person have it.

options.label: D
options.text: If you ask for honesty, you have to keep it to yourself.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's goal for his students when it comes to reading and spelling?

options.label: A
options.text: To make them read and spell as little as possible.

options.label: B
options.text: To make them read and spell until they hate it.

options.label: C
options.text: To make them read and spell until they never misspell again.

options.label: D
options.text: To make them read and spell as much as they want.

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker say he makes his students do in math class?

options.label: A
options.text: He makes them show all their work, but not on their final drafts.

options.label: B
options.text: He makes them hide all their work in math class.

options.label: C
options.text: He makes them show all their work in math class and then hide it on their final drafts.

options.label: D
options.text: He makes them do nothing in math class.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's final statement to the dinner guests about what he makes?

options.label: A
options.text: He says he makes a lot of money.

options.label: B
options.text: He says he doesn't make anything.

options.label: C
options.text: He says he makes a difference in his students' lives.

options.label: D
options.text: He says he's just a teacher.

title: The threat of invasive species - Jennifer Klos

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of an invasive species that has had a significant impact on the environment in the southeastern United States?

options.label: A
options.text: Burmese python

options.label: B
options.text: European rabbit

options.label: C
options.text: Kudzu vine

options.label: D
options.text: Zebra mussel

multiple-choice.question: Why did the kudzu vine grow uncontrollably in the southeastern United States?

options.label: A
options.text: It had natural predators in its new home.

options.label: B
options.text: It had a mild climate, sunny fields, and no natural predators.

options.label: C
options.text: It was not subsidized by the government to fight soil erosion.

options.label: D
options.text: It was not imported from its native east Asia.

multiple-choice.question: What is a limiting factor that can restrict the size or range of a species in a healthy ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: Availability of water

options.label: B
options.text: Presence or absence of predators

options.label: C
options.text: Levels of sunlight and soil nutrients

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: Why do invasive species often have a significant impact on ecosystems?

options.label: A
options.text: They are more efficient at using resources than native species.

options.label: B
options.text: They have a different set of limiting factors in their new habitat.

options.label: C
options.text: They are not susceptible to the same predators as native species.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not adapted to the new climate.

multiple-choice.question: Why are humans often responsible for the introduction of invasive species?

options.label: A
options.text: We are not aware of the consequences of introducing non-native organisms.

options.label: B
options.text: We are trying to control soil erosion by importing plants like the kudzu vine.

options.label: C
options.text: We are migrating around the world and bringing our plants and animals along.

options.label: D
options.text: We are trying to introduce new predators to control native species.

title: Can plants talk to each other? - Richard Karban

multiple-choice.question: How do plants communicate with each other?

options.label: A
options.text: Through complex sensory or nervous systems

options.label: B
options.text: Through chemical signals in response to their environments

options.label: C
options.text: Through visual signals and body language

options.label: D
options.text: Through auditory signals and vocalizations

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a plant's leaves get damaged?

options.label: A
options.text: The plant releases plumes of volatile chemicals that can be detected by other plants

options.label: B
options.text: The plant becomes more resistant to disease and pests

options.label: C
options.text: The plant grows more slowly and produces fewer flowers

options.label: D
options.text: The plant dies immediately

multiple-choice.question: Why do plants warn their neighbors of danger?

options.label: A
options.text: To compete for resources

options.label: B
options.text: To protect themselves from predators

options.label: C
options.text: It may be an accidental consequence of a self-defense mechanism

options.label: D
options.text: To attract more insects

multiple-choice.question: How do plants communicate with each other through the soil?

options.label: A
options.text: Through fungal networks that connect separate plants

options.label: B
options.text: Through underground tunnels and pipes

options.label: C
options.text: Through chemical signals that travel through the air

options.label: D
options.text: Through electromagnetic signals

multiple-choice.question: What can happen when a plant receives a warning signal from another plant?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes more susceptible to disease and pests

options.label: B
options.text: It becomes more resistant to disease and pests

options.label: C
options.text: It grows more slowly and produces fewer flowers

options.label: D
options.text: It dies immediately

title: What is abstract expressionism? - Sarah Rosenthal

multiple-choice.question: What movement in art is characterized by large, primarily abstract paintings, all-over compositions without clear focal points, and sweeping swaths of paint embodying and eliciting emotions?

options.label: A
options.text: Impressionism

options.label: B
options.text: Abstract Expressionism

options.label: C
options.text: Surrealism

options.label: D
options.text: Cubism

multiple-choice.question: What was one of the key techniques used by Jackson Pollock in his paintings?

options.label: A
options.text: Painting in small, detailed strokes

options.label: B
options.text: Using a palette knife to apply thick layers of paint

options.label: C
options.text: Dripping industrial paint onto the canvas from stirrers and other tools

options.label: D
options.text: Creating intricate patterns with a brush

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what was one of the reasons why Jackson Pollock's work has stayed prominent?

options.label: A
options.text: Because he was the first artist to use a new technique

options.label: B
options.text: Because his paintings were made up of intricate patterns

options.label: C
options.text: Because his work embodied fascinating contradictions

options.label: D
options.text: Because he was a celebrity

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the characteristics of Pollock's paintings that seems to defy all control, but is actually the product of a deliberate process?

options.label: A
options.text: The use of bright colors

options.label: B
options.text: The creation of intricate patterns

options.label: C
options.text: The illusion of an infinite layered depth

options.label: D
options.text: The use of bold brushstrokes

multiple-choice.question: What was one of the effects of the work of the New York School of artists, including Jackson Pollock?

options.label: A
options.text: They created a new style of art that was widely accepted

options.label: B
options.text: They destroyed conventions of painting that had stood for centuries

options.label: C
options.text: They created a new movement in art that was rejected by the art world

options.label: D
options.text: They created a new style of art that was only appreciated by only a few people

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The International Prototype Kilogram

options.text: The Silicon Sphere

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Kilogram

options.label: C
options.text: Grave

What is the proposed method to redefine the kilogram, which involves fixing Planck's constant and using a Watt Balance?

title: Why do cats act so weird? - Tony Buffington

multiple-choice.question: What is one reason why cats are drawn to small spaces and containers?

options.label: A
options.text: They are curious about the contents inside.

options.label: B
options.text: They are trying to escape from a predator.

options.label: C
options.text: They are following their natural instinct to stalk and pounce on prey.

options.label: D
options.text: They are looking for a place to rest.

multiple-choice.question: Why do cats sharpen their claws?

options.label: A
options.text: To strengthen their nails.

options.label: B
options.text: To mark their territory.

options.label: C
options.text: To climb, hunt, and defend themselves.

options.label: D
options.text: To show affection.

multiple-choice.question: What is one possible reason why cats purr?

options.label: A
options.text: To communicate with other cats.

options.label: B
options.text: To express happiness or stress.

options.label: C
options.text: To promote tissue regeneration.

options.label: D
options.text: To attract attention.

multiple-choice.question: Why do cats prefer a clean and odor-free litter box?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they like the smell of the litter.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they want to mark their territory.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it helps them avoid detection by predators.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's more comfortable.

multiple-choice.question: In the eyes of a cat, what are humans?

options.label: A
options.text: Predators that they need to outsmart.

options.label: B
options.text: Prey that they need to hunt.

options.label: C
options.text: Companions that provide food and shelter.

options.label: D
options.text: Competitors for resources.

title: Why is being scared so fun? - Margee Kerr

multiple-choice.question: What is one reason why people might enjoy being scared, even though it may seem counterintuitive?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a way to punish themselves for being weak.

options.label: B
options.text: It's a way to avoid responsibility.

options.label: C
options.text: It can trigger a natural high, similar to excitement or happiness.

options.label: D
options.text: It's a way to show off to others.

multiple-choice.question: What is one possible explanation for why some people are more prone to thrill-seeking than others?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a higher pain tolerance.

options.label: B
options.text: They are more likely to be in a safe environment.

options.label: C
options.text: They have differences in how the chemicals associated with the threat response work in their bodies.

options.label: D
options.text: They are more likely to be in a group of friends.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way in which fear can affect people's behavior and relationships?

options.label: A
options.text: It can cause people to become isolated and withdrawn.

options.label: B
options.text: It can bring people together and create a sense of closeness.

options.label: C
options.text: It can cause people to become more competitive and aggressive.

options.label: D
options.text: It can cause people to become less empathetic and less understanding.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way in which fear can be beneficial for individuals?

options.label: A
options.text: It can help them avoid making mistakes.

options.label: B
options.text: It can give them a sense of accomplishment and boost their self-esteem.

options.label: C
options.text: It can help them become more anxious and stressed.

options.label: D
options.text: It can help them become more reckless and impulsive.

multiple-choice.question: What is one reason why people might want to repeat experiences that trigger a strong fear response?

options.label: A
options.text: They want to relive the experience of being scared.

options.label: B
options.text: They want to show off to others and prove their bravery.

options.label: C
options.text: They want to remember the experience and the emotions associated with it.

options.label: D
options.text: They want to forget the experience and move on.

title: The backwards brain bicycle: un-doing understanding

multiple-choice.question: What happened to Destin in Amsterdam that made him realize he couldn't ride a bike like he used to?

options.label: A
options.text: He fell off the bike.

options.label: B
options.text: He damaged his mind.

options.label: C
options.text: He couldn't remember how to ride a bike.

options.label: D
options.text: He was too scared to ride a bike.

multiple-choice.question: What was the challenge that Destin's friend Barney gave him, and how did he respond?

options.label: A
options.text: Barney challenged Destin to ride a bike with training wheels, and Destin was excited to take it on.

options.label: B
options.text: Barney challenged Destin to ride a bike with one pedal, and Destin laughed it off.

options.label: C
options.text: Barney challenged Destin to ride a bike with a reversed handlebar, and Destin was initially frustrated but eventually learned to ride it.

options.label: D
options.text: Barney challenged Destin to ride a bike with a heavy load, and Destin refused to try.

multiple-choice.question: What did Destin learn from his experience of trying to ride a backwards bike?

options.label: A
options.text: He learned that he was too old to learn new things.

options.label: B
options.text: He learned that knowledge is not understanding.

options.label: C
options.text: He learned that he was too scared to ride a bike.

options.label: D
options.text: He learned that he needed to practice more.

multiple-choice.question: How long did it take Destin's son to learn how to ride a backwards bike?

options.label: A
options.text: 2 months

options.label: B
options.text: 2 weeks

options.label: C
options.text: 8 months

options.label: D
options.text: 1 year

multiple-choice.question: What did Destin realize after trying to ride a normal bike in Amsterdam?

options.label: A
options.text: He realized that he was still a good rider.

options.label: B
options.text: He realized that he had forgotten how to ride a bike.

options.label: C
options.text: He realized that his brain had adapted to the new algorithm.

options.label: D
options.text: He realized that he was faking the previous 20 minutes of struggling to ride a bike.

title: The surprising reason you feel awful when you're sick - Marco A. Sotomayor

multiple-choice.question: What triggers the immune system to launch a stronger attack when a virus enters the body?

options.label: A
options.text: The release of cytokines by macrophages

options.label: B
options.text: The infection of cells by the virus

options.label: C
options.text: The coordination of the immune system with the brain

options.label: D
options.text: The presence of symptoms such as aches and pains

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the unpleasant symptoms such as fever, aches, and sleepiness when the immune system is under attack?

options.label: A
options.text: To make the person feel more comfortable

options.label: B
options.text: To aid in recovery by slowing bacteria and helping the immune system destroy pathogens

options.label: C
options.text: To distract the person from the infection

options.label: D
options.text: To make the person more susceptible to infection

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of cytokines in the immune response?

options.label: A
options.text: To recruit and organize more virus-busting cells from the immune system

options.label: B
options.text: To destroy infected cells

options.label: C
options.text: To slow the spread of the virus

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the body temperature

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of the immune system's response on the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: It disrupts the activity of neurotransmitters, leading to irritability, sadness, and confusion

options.label: B
options.text: It increases the production of serotonin and dopamine

options.label: C
options.text: It reduces the production of cytokines

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on the brain

multiple-choice.question: What is an autoimmune disease?

options.label: A
options.text: A disease in which the immune system treats normal bodily cues as threats

options.label: B
options.text: A disease in which the immune system is weakened

options.label: C
options.text: A disease in which the immune system is overactive

options.label: D
options.text: A disease in which the immune system is not functioning at all
